title-group.article-title: The Effective Tax Burden of Companies and of Highly Skilled Manpower: Tax Policy Strategies in a Globalised Economy

abstract.p: Company taxes and taxes on highly skilled labour both influence the attractiveness of a particular region as a location for investment. We measure the effective tax burden on capital investment and on highly qualified labour in 33 locations across Europe and the United States. We then correlate both types of tax burden in order to study the different tax policy strategies applied in different countries. We find that effective tax rates on companies and on highly skilled employees are closely correlated for a number of countries. Ireland and most new EU Member States impose relatively lower taxes on capital investment than on highly skilled manpower. Conversely, in the US, companies are taxed heavily but the effective tax rate on highly skilled employees is moderate.

p.mixed-citation: The estimations were prepared for the IBC BAK International Benchmark Club®, an initiative by BAK Basel Economics, which evaluates and compares economic performance and location factors across European regions. The authors thank the IBC for financing this research and the steering group of the IBC module 'Taxation' for helpful discussions.

For employees, amenities such as schools, environmental quality and transportation systems are clearly relevant for the decision to settle at a location. Similarly, cost-of-living differentials are obviously important for migration decisions. While we are aware of this, we purposely abstract from these issues so as to be able to isolate tax differentials across locations.
See, for example, Griliches (1969), Bergström and Panas (1992) and Krusell et al. (2000) for evidence of capital-skill complementarity.
See Devereux and Griffith (1998) and Büttner and Ruf (2006).
See Devereux and Griffith (1999 and 2003) and Schreiber, Spengel and Lammersen (2002).
See, for example, OECD (1991), European Commission (2002) and Jacobs et al. (2004).
A formal description is provided in Elschner and Schwager (2006).

It is adequate to disregard taxes at the shareholder level in case managers do not know the tax position of their marginal shareholder. Moreover, domestic shareholder taxation does not affect corporate investment decisions of multinationals if capital is highly mobile internationally. For a discussion of these issues, see European Commission (2002, p. 142).

This discussion, which obviously must remain speculative to some extent, is not meant to replace a thorough empirical analysis. Instead, it aims to suggest some political motives and economic circumstances that may have caused the levels of taxation found in our study.
For an assessment of the tax autonomy of subnational governments, see Stegarescu (2005b).
